2021 Projects and Writing Recap

Tue Dec 21 2021

Tags: memo

This is like what Spotify comes up with at the end of the year, except I made it myself.

I've learned I need to build and write. They're both important to me. Building apps makes me a better writer, and technical writing makes me a better developer. Here's what I've been up to this year on each of these fronts, plus a few other notes.

Building

Write Things

Write Things (Source Code) is a React app that helps you write in a carrot-on-a-stick sort of way—you'll get a new picture every few words you write. You can select how often you'd like the app to do this. You can write plain text, or code with syntax highlighting.

Rapt

Rapt (Source Code) is a full-stack app built with Node, Express, MongoDB, and Mongoose. It's a time-tracker that lets you annotate your Pomodoro sessions, and provides a visual summary of your work using the D3.js library. The app uses server-side rendering with EJS, a templating language. Users register and log in using local authentication.

Task Lemon

Task Lemon is a full stack MVP that's almost ready to ship. I wrote some internal docs, and several pages on the project's wiki. It's tailored for instructors who want to run courses without a syllabus. This was the largest dev team project I've worked on, and I'm excited to see it used in bootcamps and workshops and conferences.

Yes, But How?

This is the blog you're reading right now! I made it from scratch with a static site generator, Eleventy. It was one of my early ventures away from entirely imperative JavaScript code, and a good stepping stone towards mildly-to-strongly-opinionated libraries and frameworks.

Writing

My rock-paper-scissors-lizard-spock game is the post I hear about the most from some very kind people, and I hope it helps them continue on into the land of vanilla JavaScript. My post about GitHub Copilot is my personal favourite. It's an example of supporting for new devs by leveraging some overlooked tools.

The rest of my posts are inspired by things I've encountered, or by questions I've gotten from others, and those questions often ended in, "Yes, but how?" It only made sense that I wrote about those discussions on this blog.

Open Source Contributions

Code Thesaurus

I made a pull request that fixed a layout issue. It was my first time working with Django and Bootstrap. I figured out how to set up a local development environment on my machine, and it was my first dive into containerization and Docker.

Plans for 2022

Keep writing at least one blog post per month. In order to pull this off, I'll need to keep the conversation going with developers at all levels. There's only so much I can discover and discern on my own. Book clubs and reading in general help a lot too.
Keep building apps. The driver for this might be checking out new libraries and frameworks. I don't necessarily need to do a deep dive into every single one, but knowing what's possible can be a source of creativity. It's okay if most of these apps never see the light of day. There are other ways for the effort to pay off.
Start reaching out to more people. I'm an introvert, through and through. With the pandemic, I'm rusty when it comes to navigating new social settings. It's going to be uncomfortable, but I need to remember it's also rewarding.

Thanks for reading! I hope it was useful. I'd love to hear your thoughts over on Twitter.
